questions.text: A 24-year-old man presented with progressive swelling and pain in his right lower limb. X-ray shows findings seen in the image below and a CT scan of the chest reveals osteoblastic metastases. What is the most common location of this underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of bone swelling and pain with imaging revealing Codman's triangle is suggestive of osteosarcoma. The most common location of this disease is the distal femoral metaphysis.

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor. It is characterized by osteoid production by malignant cells. It has a bimodal age distribution, occurring in adolescence (10–14 years) and again in the 7th decade of life.

Patients present with localized pain and a soft tissue mass. Most times metastasis is already present at diagnosis such as in this patient. Night pain may be seen in some patients.

Diagnosis involves an X-ray initially. The X-ray shows the destruction of the normal trabecular bone pattern, indistinct margins, and no endosteal bone response. Periosteal new bone formation presents as the formation of Codman's triangle. It refers to the part where new bone forms in response to periosteal elevation. A sunburst pattern may be seen and it occurs when the periosteum does not have time to lay down a new layer. Instead, the Sharpey’s fibers stretch perpendicular to the periosteum causing this pattern.

MRI is the best imaging modality to measure the extent of the spread of the tumor into the bone and adjacent structures. A bone scan is used to detect skeletal metastases, and a CT of the chest is done to search for lung metastases. This is because the lungs are the most common site of metastases.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the wound shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The wound shown in the image is best described as an abrasion wound on the hand.

Abrasions are superficial wounds produced due to the destruction of the epidermis. Though exact age cannot be determined, based on healing and appearance of the wound, an estimated time can be given.

Abrasion types:

  • Linear abrasions (scratches): caused by relative movement of a pointed object on the skin
    • Ex: nail, thorn, the point of sword or knife
  • Grazed abrasions (sliding /scrapping/grinding abrasion): caused by relative movement of a rough surface on a wide area of skin.
    • known as brush burns; are the most common type of abrasions
    • Ex: fall, a victim being dragged on the ground, road traffic accidents
  • Imprint abrasions (patterned abrasions): caused by the impact of a rigid hard rough surface over a localized area of the skin without any movement
    • Ex: fingernail, tire, grills, bicycle chain, bite marks
  • Friction abrasions (pressure abrasion): are caused by crushing of the superficial layers of the epidermis.
    • Ex: ligature marks around the neck in hanging,

Other options:

Option A: A bruise or a contusion occurs due to blunt trauma that causes rupture of underlying blood vessels and extravasation of the blood into surrounding tissues. A fresh bruise is usually tender and is slightly raised above the surface of the skin. It has a lighter colour in the center because the extravasated blood is pushed outward by the impact of the trauma. A picture of a bruise is shown below:

 

Option B: A puncture wound is a stab wound that is produced when force is delivered along the long axis of a narrow or pointed object such as a knife, dagger, or sword into the soft tissues of the body. An image of a puncture wound is shown below:

 

Option D: A scald burn is an injury that occurs when the skin comes in contact with any liquid at a temperature above 60ºC or steam. Immediate redness is observed at the site followed by blistering. With the removal of the blistered skin, a pink raw surface is observed which later becomes brownish, hard, and dry. An image of a scald burn is shown below:

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of crushing chest pain radiating to the jaw and dysphagia. It starts whenever he has ice cream and he takes sublingual nitroglycerin which provides him relief. He underwent manometry which showed simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg). What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with episodes triggered by cold foods and manometric findings are suggestive of a diffuse esophageal spasm (DES).

Diffuse esophageal spasm is a hypermotility disorder of the esophagus. It is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the esophageal body. It is more common in women. 

Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain. Pathologically, there is marked hypertrophy of the circular muscles. It is often triggered by cold foods. It mimics symptoms of myocardial infarction and also shows improvement when sublingual nitroglycerin is administered. It causes smooth muscle relaxation of the esophagus. 

A barium swallow shows a corkscrew esophagus. However, manometry (high-resolution manometry is preferred) is the gold standard test for diagnosis. In classic manometry, if there are simultaneous, multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mmHg) or long duration (>2.5 seconds) it is suggestive of diffuse esophageal spasm.

On high-resolution manometry, a DCI (distal contractile integral) >450 mmHg is suggestive of DES. The distal contractile integral (DCI) is an index of contractile vigor in high-resolution manometry, calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction.

Hypertensive lower esophageal sphincter - It is achalasia in evolution. Shows increased LES pressure but normal peristalsis.

Nutcracker’s esophagus - In conventional manometry, it shows a high-amplitude peristaltic contraction ( >180mmHg) and a longer duration of contraction (>7sec).

In high-resolution manometry, a DCI > 8000mmHg is suggestive of nutcracker's esophagus.

questions.text: The instrument used for the assessment of rectocele and cystocele is _______
questions.solution:
Sim's speculum is used for assessment of rectocele and cystocele.

The speculum is applied against the vaginal wall and slowly retracted out until a bulge appears, indicating cystocele or rectocele.  It can also be used for visualisation of the vaginal walls.

Cusco’s speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum used for visualisation of the cervix, vaginal fornices and for performing pap smear.

Auvard speculum is used during vaginal hysterectomy. It retracts the posterior vaginal wall and has a weighted handle that makes it self-retaining.

The Veda-scope is a recently developed alternative to bivalve speculums. The instrument creates an air tight seal at the vaginal introitus and the vagina is inflated with filtered air. Following inflation, the vaginal walls can be examined and tests such as VIA VILI (Visual inspection with acetic acid and lugol’s iodine) and pap smear can be performed. It also allows for taking pictures with a camera and introducing a light source.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: An Intraocular lens was placed uneventfully in a young patient during cataract surgery. What should be done then?
questions.solution:
Uneventful intraocular lens placement, is not an indication for replacing the IOL. 

An IOL replacement (IOL exchange) may be done under the following conditions:

  • Incorrect IOL placed
  • Posterior or anterior dislocation of IOL
  • Hyphema
  • Asymmetrical Haptic Placement
  • Sunset Syndrome
  • Lens-Bag Decentration

Option C: In the event that secondary catarct develops, it is treated by surgical or laser (Nd:YaG) posterior capsulotomy.

Option D: Presbyopia is a disorder of accomdation seen in old age. It is usually corrected by prescription unifocal or Bifocal or multifocal glasses or contact lenses.

questions.text: A hospital has reported an outbreak of MRSA infection. On investigation, it was found out that a staff nurse had nasal carriage of MRSA. Which of the following drugs helps in the removal of colonization of bacteria?
questions.solution:
Topical mupirocin is the preferred agent for the elimination of nasal carriers of MRSA.

As Mupirocin has no structural similarities with existing systemic antibiotics that might lead to the development of cross-resistance and has minimal toxicity in its topical form, it is approved for the prevention of MRSA outbreaks

Mixed therapy with systemic agents is not preferred as it would cause unnecessary antibiotic exposure potentially paving way for drug resistance. 

Mupirocin is a unique antimicrobial agent because of its structure and mechanism of action. Mupirocin exerts its antimicrobial activity by reversibly inhibiting isoleucyl-transfer RNA, thereby inhibiting bacterial protein and RNA synthesis.

questions.text: A woman met with an accident 4 days back in which her child was severely injured. She now has repeated memories, flashbacks, and distressing dreams about the accident. She now tries to avoid the memories and people who were present during the incident. She appears quiet, but there are anger outbursts. She has difficulty sleeping and has an exaggerated startle response. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes acute stress disorder.

Diagnosis of acute stress disorder:

  • A person has exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violation.
  • Presence of nine or more of the following symptoms
    • Recurrent, involuntary, and intrusive distressing memories 
    • Recurrent distressing dreams related to the event
    • Dissociative reactions (e.g., flashbacks) in which the individual feels or acts as if the traumatic event(s) were recurring.
    • Intense psychological distress
    • Inability to experience happiness, satisfaction, or love feelings
    • An altered sense of the reality of one's surroundings or oneself 
    • Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event
    • Efforts to avoid distressing memories, thoughts
    • Efforts to avoid people, places, or conversations related to the incident
    • Sleep disturbances
    • Irritable behaviour and angry outbursts
    • Hypervigilance
    • Increased startle response
  • The duration of the disturbance is 3 days to 1 month after trauma exposure
  • These disturbances cause significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning 
  • The disturbances are not attributable to any medical condition, medications, or alcohol.

Other options:

Option A: In post-traumatic stress disorder, the patient has similar symptoms to an acute stress disorder, but the duration of the disturbance is more than 1 month.

Option B: In adjustment disorder, the patient develops behavioural or emotional symptoms within 3 months of the onset of stressors. The distress is out of proportion to the severity or intensity of the stressor. Once the stressor has been eliminated, the symptoms do not last for more than 6 months. 

Option D: Bereavement is seen immediately or within a few months after the loss of a loved one. Typical signs and symptoms include feelings of sadness, preoccupation with thoughts about the deceased, tearfulness, irritability, insomnia, and difficulties concentrating and carrying out daily activities. It usually lasts for less than 6 months.

questions.text:
Which of the following are risk factors for breast cancer?

1 - Alcohol
2 - Multiparity
3 - Early menarche
4 - Breastfeeding
5 - Postmenopausal Obesity
questions.solution:
Risk factors for breast cancer among the options given are  - alcohol, early menarche, and obesity.

Postmenopausal obesity is thought to increase the risk of breast cancer due to increased peripheral estrogen conversion. 

Similarly, factors that increase endogenous estrogen such as - menarche when younger than 13 years (2 times the risk), nulliparity, first full pregnancy when older than 30 years, not breastfeeding, and menopause when older than 50 years increase the number of menstrual cycles also increase the risk of breast cancer.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors and Protective Factors for Breast Carcinoma

Risk factors:

  • Age: Incidence increases with increasing age.
  • Sex: more common in females.
  • Family history of breast cancer
  • Race, ethnicity (white women have increased risk compared to women of other races)
  • History of radiation exposure
  • Mammographically dense breast
  • Genetic factors:
  • Mutations in tumor suppressor genes:
    • BRCA 1
    • BRCA 2
    • TP53
    • CHEK2
  • Hereditary syndromes:
    • Li Fraumeni syndrome
    • Cowden’s syndrome
    • HNPCC syndrome
    • Peutz-Jegher’s syndrome
    • Ataxia telangiectasia
  • Hormonal factors (hyperestrogenemia is the risk factor):
    • Early menarche
    • Late menopause
    • First full-term pregnancy >30 years
    • Nulliparity
    • Obesity (postmenopausal)
  • Higher socioeconomic status, high fat diet, alcohol intake

Protective factors:

  • Early age at first pregnancy
  • Multiparity
  • Breastfeeding
  • Oophorectomy
  • Exercise
  • Tamoxifen and Aromatase inhibitors

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with rigidity, frequent falls, slowness in his movements, tremors, and had short stepping gait when he entered the doctor's room. Which of the following areas, is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Parkinson's disease, which is associated with the degeneration of substantia nigra (marked as "C").

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease,  there is an absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Postural instability along with bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor are cardinal features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

Notable gait abnormalities are:

  • Short stepped gait- parkinsonism
  • Scissoring gait- spasticity i.e. UMN lesion
  • High-stepped, slapping gait- posterior column or peripheral nerve disease
  • Waddling gait- proximal muscle weakness
  • Wide stepping gait - cerebellar dysfunction

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child with  Incontinentia pigmenti presented with the following findings. The lesions shown in the below image are usually seen in which stage of Incontinentia pigmenti?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Hyperpigmented skin lesions, which are usually seen in stage 3 of Incontinentia pigmenti

Incontinentia pigmenti is an X-linked dominant disorder with multisystemic ectodermal dysplasia that is usually lethal in males. It presents in females with skin lesions, teeth abnormalities, alopecia, nail dystrophy, and ocular and neurological findings.

The lesions can be described in 4 distinct stages, which are

  • Stage 1 - Erythematous vesicular rash
  • Stage 2 - Verrucous lesions
  • Stage 3 - Hyperpigmented streaks and whorls
  • Stage 4 - Hypopigmented Patches

Management:

  • No specific treatment is available
  • Symptomatic treatment includes standard management of blisters
  • Ophthalmological follow‐up is required for retinal neovascularization monitoring and treatment

questions.text:
A 30-year-old drowsy male was brought to the casualty by his colleague He is a mechanic by profession and he was found in this state in the garage, next to an empty bottle of antifreeze. His pulse was 130/min, respiratory rate -30/min, blood gas analysis revealed metabolic acidosis, hypocalcemia, blood Urea – 100 mg/dl, S. creatinine – 3.4 mg/dl. Urine analysis showed Calcium oxalate crystals. Which of the following is/are a part of his treatment?
  1. Nasogastric aspiration
  2. 4-methyl-pyrazole
  3. Ethyl alcohol
  4. Sodium bicarbonate
  5. Calcium gluconate
  6. Dialysis
questions.solution:
This patient's history and clinical features are suggestive of Ethylene glycol poisoning. All the above-mentioned modalities are used in the treatment of ethylene glycol poisoning depending on the symptoms and severity.

This patient presented with acute onset CNS depression (drowsiness), tachycardia (130/min), and tachypnoea (30/min). On preliminary lab analysis, he was found to have metabolic acidosis, acute kidney injury (elevated BUN & S. creatinine) with hypocalcemia - most likely due to precipitation of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine. All these features, particularly including the presence of renal failure (AKI) points towards Ethylene glycol poisoning. Antifreeze used in automobile cooling systems contains ethylene glycol.

This patient's treatment includes:

  • Nasogastric lavage & aspiration to remove the residual substance
  • Sodium bicarbonate to counter falling pH from metabolic acidosis
  • Calcium gluconate 10% to treat the hypocalcemia)
  • 4-methyl pyrazole (Fomipezole) - Alcohol Dehydrogenase inhibitor to inhibit the metabolic conversion of ethylene glycol to glyoxyaldehyde which is toxic to the kidneys.
  • Ethanol acts as a competitive inhibitor to ethylene glycol for the enzyme, alcohol dehydrogenase, thereby limiting the conversion of ethylene glycol to toxic metabolites.
  • Hemodialysis is used in patients with serum ethylene glycol concentration > 50mg/dL, or those with significant renal impairment or metabolic acisosis.

NOTE: Methyl alcohol (Methanol) and Ethylene glycol poisoning can present very similarly. However, the key distinguishing feature of Methanol poisoning is the presence of eye symptoms (as opposed to kidney damage in ethylene glycol) - like blurring of vision/loss of vision due to retinal damage by formate metabolites.

Methanol--Alcohol Dehydrogenase (ADH) ⇒ Formaldehyde (Retinal damage)

Ethylene glycol--Alcohol Dehydrogenase (ADH) ⇒ Glyoxyaldehyde ⇒ (Kidney damage) 

Related Pearl: Dialyzable and non-dialyzable drugs

Common dialyzable drugs: 

  • Barbiturates
  • Lithium
  • Salicylates
  • Theophylline/Caffeine (both are methylxanthines)
  • Methanol
  • Ethylene glycol
  • Sodium valproate
  • Isoniazid
  • Carbamazepine

Common Non-Dialyzable Drugs (AVOID Dialysis):

  • A- Amphetamines
  • V- Verapamil
  • O- Opiates, Organophosphorous
  • I- Imipramine
  • D- Digoxin
  • Dialysis- Diazepam

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male patient presented with a 3-week history of yellow skin and sclerae but is otherwise asymptomatic. There is a history of similar episodes 2 years back. Occasionally, he has noticed dark-colored urine. LFT is given below. A liver biopsy, stained with Fontana-Masson stain is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Serum bilirubin - 4.4 mg/dL (Predominantly conjugated)

Serum AST, ALT- Normal
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the liver biopsy showing characteristic deposition of pigment are suggestive of Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and brown-black melanin-like pigment deposition in the liver which can lead to a gross black appearance of the liver. The disease is caused by the mutation in the multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP-2) gene in hepatocytes, which is required for the transport of non-bile salt organic anions at the canalicular membranes.

Total bilirubin concentrations are typically between 2 and 5 mg/dL and can fluctuate widely in patients. Hyper-bilirubinemia may be increased by current illness, oral contraceptive use, and pregnancy. Aside from elevated serum bilirubin levels, other routine laboratory tests (eg Liver Function tests) are normal. 

Other options:

Option A: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is a type of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that occurs due to a decrease in UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UDPGT) activity. Type 1 has absent/trace UDPGT enzyme activity and type 2 has <10% of the normal UDPGT enzyme activity.

Option C: Budd Chiari syndrome is characterized by obstruction of hepatic venous outflow. It is a clinical complex characterized by hepatomegaly, ascites and abdominal pain.

Option D: Gilbert syndrome is a type of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that occurs due to reduced UDPGT enzyme activity (10-33% of Normal).

questions.text:
A patient after thyroid surgery develops dyspnoea and stridor without any change in voice. Which of the following nerve is injured?

B/L - Bilateral

U/L - Unilateral

choices.text: U/L superior laryngeal and recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.solution:
Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerves are injured in this case.

In bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis (B/L abductor paralysis), all the intrinsic muscles of larynx (except cricothyroid) are paralyzed. Vocal cords lie in median or paramedian position due to unopposed action of cricothyroid muscles. 

Classically, they present with airway compromise leading to dyspnoea and stridor. Voice quality is not affected as the paralysed cords assume their natural adducted position during phonation.

Other options

Option A: In bilateral superior laryngeal nerve paralysis, both the cricothyroid muscles are paralyzed with anaesthesia of upper larynx. Patients present with aspiration of food, cough, and choking fits with a weak and husky voice.

Option C: In unilateral superior laryngeal and recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis (complete paralysis), all the muscles of larynx on one side are paralyzed. Vocal cord on the affected side will lie in cadaveric position. Glottic incompetence occurs as the healthy cord is unable to approximate the paralyzed cord.  They present with hoarseness of voice, aspiration of food, and ineffective cough.

Option D: In unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis, ipsilateral paralysis of all the intrinsic muscles (except cricothyroid) occurs. Vocal cord on the affected side lie in median or paramedian position. Patient maybe asymptomatic. Few may present with voice changes. However, aspiration and airway obstruction does not occur.

Nerve injured Clinical features
Unilateral recurrent layngeal nerve paralysis
  • Asymptomatic
  • Few may have change in voice
  • No airway obstruction/ aspiration
Bilateral recurrent layngeal nerve paralysis
  • Airway obstruction (dyspnea, stridor)
  • No change in voice
Unilateral superior layngeal nerve paralysis
  • Weak voice with inability to raise the pitch
  • Anaesthesia of larynx on one side causing occasional aspiration
Bilateral superior layngeal nerve paralysis
  • Aspiration of food (cough, choking)
  • Weak and husky voice
Unilateral recurrent and superior layngeal nerve paralysis (complete paralysis)
  • Hoarseness of voice
  • Aspiration of food
  • Ineffective cough
Bilateral recurrent and superior layngeal nerve paralysis (complete paralysis)
  • Aphonia
  • Aspiration of food
  • Inability to cough

questions.text: A 52-year-old male who is a known case of hypertension, came to the hospital with a complaint of lower back pain. His BP was 154/90 mm of Hg, and serum creatinine was 2.5 mg/dL. However, the patient’s BP and creatinine levels were within normal limits when he last visited. A careful history revealed that the patient was taking NSAIDs for the past few months for knee pain. He also started exercising to alleviate knee pain. Which of the following events is likely responsible for the increase in serum creatinine concentration?

choices.text: Increased muscle mass due to exercise

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the use of NSAIDs caused increased afferent arteriolar resistance.

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) inhibit the synthesis of prostaglandins leading to constriction of afferent arterioles. As a result, the afferent arteriolar resistance is increased leading to reduced GFR. The decrease in GFR, in turn, leads to an increase in serum creatinine.

Other options:

  • Increased efferent arteriole resistance and increased glomerular capillary filtration coefficient both causes an increase in GFR.
  • Increasing muscle mass due to exercise does not have any significant effect on serum creatinine.

questions.text: A child is brought to the OPD with lesions in the perioral area as seen in the image below. Histopathology of the lesion revealed subepidermal blistering with a dense neutrophilic infiltrate. Direct immunofluorescence of the perilesional skin demonstrated a linear deposition of IgA antibodies at the dermal-epidermal junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is chronic bullous dermatosis of childhood. The image shows blisters and crusts with a "string of pearls” pattern in the perioral region and the presence of linear IgA deposits at the dermal-epidermal junction is diagnostic.

Chronic bullous dermatosis (Linear Ig A Dermatosis) of childhood is an autoimmune blistering disease in infants and children. The disease can also be seen in adults and is known as Linear IgA disease of adults or IgA bullous pemphigoid.

Tense blisters and vesicles with erythema are seen. They are arranged annularly in a “crown of jewels” or “string of pearls” formation, although this sign is not pathognomic. Varying degrees of pruritis may be present. The most common sites are the perioral area and perineum, followed by the trunk and limbs.

It may be seen as a drug eruption, and most drug-induced cases are related to vancomycin.

  • Biopsy of the lesion: Subepidermal splitting and neutrophil infiltration in the papillary dermis, sometimes forming microabscesses.
  • Direct immunofluorescence of perilesional skin: Linear deposits of predominantly IgA at the epidermal basement membrane zone (dermo-epidermal junction).

Treatment:

  • 1st line
    • Dapsone
    • Topical steroids +/- prednisolone
  • 2nd line
    • Sulfa drugs -sulfapyridine, sulfamethoxypyridazine
    • Anti‐inflammatory antibiotics - oxytetracycline, doxycycline) ± nicotinamide
  • Third line
    • Mycophenolate
    • IVIG
    • Immunoadsorption

The image below shows Linear IgA dermatosis at various sites.

 

 

Histopathology of Linear IgA dermatosis showing subepidermal blister formation and neutrophils is given below.

Other options:

Option A: Dermatitis herpetiformis - On direct IF microscopy, granular deposits of IgA in the dermal papillae are seen. Antibodies against epidermal and or tissue transglutaminase will also be present. 

An image of dermatitis herpetiformis is shown below.

Option C: Bullous impetigo is a superficial skin infection with S. Aureus. Histopathology shows epidermal splitting just below the stratum granulo­sum, with neutrophil migration into the blister cavity. There is spongiosis, and cocci may be seen with certain stains. The culture of the blister fluid yields colonies of S. aureus.

An image of Bullous impetigo is shown below.

Option D: IgA Pemphigus -  On direct IF microscopy, deposits of IgA within the epidermis are seen. In some patients, anti-epidermal IgA antibodies may be detected.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was evaluated for delayed developmental milestones. Fundus examination revealed the findings as shown in the image below. The abdominal examination is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a fundus image showing a cherry-red spot at the macula is suggestive of Tay-Sachs disease. 

Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder due to the deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A which degrades GM2 gangliosides. GM2 ganglioside accumulates more commonly in neurons of the central and autonomic nervous systems and retina.

Tay-Sachs disease is common among people from the Ashkenazi Jewish population. Affected infants usually present with loss of motor skills, exaggerated startle response to noise (hyperacusis), seizures, and macrocephaly without hydrocephalus.

On examination of the fundus, a cherry-red spot appears in the macula in almost all patients. This is produced by the accentuation of the red color of the macular choroid, against the background of the rest of the retina appearing pale due to ganglion cells being swollen with GM2 ganglioside.

Histopathological examination reveals ballooned-out neuronal tissue with vacuoles representing lysosomes filled with gangliosides.

Note that cherry red spots are associated with multiple conditions, as discussed in the pearl below and should always be interpreted in the context of the clinical history.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with dyspnea. She had been complaining of fatigue and worsening dyspnoea over the last 3-5 days. Examination revealed BP of 80/50 mmHg, tachypnea, tachycardia, elevated neck veins, and muffled heart sounds. The echocardiography finding is shown below. Which of the following findings is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation with the classic Beck's triad and the echo showing the swinging heart sign are indicative of the diagnosis being cardiac tamponade. Physical examination would reveal the presence of pulsus paradoxus in this patient.

This patient has the classic Beck's triad of cardiac tamponade:

  • Hypotension
  • Muffled heart sounds
  • Raised jugular venous pressure (elevated neck veins) with a prominent x descent(early systolic) but an absent y(early diastolic)descent. 

The echocardiography shows swinging heart sign, which is characteristic of cardiac tamponade. The pericardial pressures exceed the left ventricular diastolic filling pressures, causing the collapse of the left ventricular free wall during diastole.

Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration. In cardiac tamponade, the ventricles are covered by an incompressible pericardial sac with increased pressure in the pericardial sac. Increased blood flows into the right ventricle during inspiration causes the interventricular septum to bulge into the left ventricle, which in turn causes a reduction in left ventricular volume, stroke volume, and arterial blood pressure. This inspiratory fall in systolic pressure is an exaggerated consequence of interventricular dependence. Severe cases may show weakening or disappearance of arterial pulse on palpation during inspiration.

Other causes of pulsus paradoxus include:

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Severe obstructive lung disease
  • Hemorrhagic shock

ECG in a patient with cardiac tamponade shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans. Electrical alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction. When the heart is nearer to the chest wall, the amplitude deflection on the ECG is increased; in contrast, when the heart moves away from the chest wall, the amplitude deflection is lower. 

 

Management of cardiac tamponade -   Intravenous infusion of normal saline improves the cardiac haemodynamics in a significant proportion of tamponade patients. The best course of action is performing pericardiocentesis, preferably carried out under echocardiographic guidance. In cases of recurrent tamponade, a small catheter may be left in place to drain subsequent collections of fluid. 

Other options:

Option B: Pulsus bisferiens also known as bifid pulse has two systolic peaks. It is seen in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. There is a rapid upstroke to the first peak (percussion wave) and a slower rise to the second peak (tidal wave). It is also rarely appreciated in patients with severe aortic regurgitation.

Option C: Pulsus parvus et tardus refers to a weak pulse (parvus), which rises slowly to a delayed peak (tardus) seen in aortic stenosis.

Option D: Pulsus alternans is defined as beat-to-beat variability in the amplitude of the pulse. It is seen in patients with severe LV dysfunction.

questions.text: A clinical pharmacologist is studying the effect of the first-pass metabolism on the systemic availability and absorption of the drug 'X'. Drug 'X' is an oral formulation whose experimental absorption value was predicted to be 1. Hepatic clearance determined for this drug is 60L/ kg/hr. Considering the normal hepatic blood flow in a healthy individual to be 90L/kg/hr, calculate the systemic bioavailability for Drug 'X'.
questions.solution:
The systemic bioavailability of this drug is 33%.

The systemic bioavailability (F) of a drug is based on the extraction ratio (ER) and the extent of absorption of the drug (f).

F = f x (1-ER)

Extraction ratio is the parameter used to express the effect of hepatic first-pass metabolism on the drug.

ER = CL(liver clearance) / Q (Blood flow to the liver)

Thus, ER = 60 / 90 = 0.67

In the given question f= 1.

Thus, F = 1 X (1-0.67) = 0.33 OR 33%

questions.text: The X-ray of a 39-year-old man who was being evaluated for backache is given below. What is the earliest sign that would be seen radiographically in this condition?

choices.text: Erosion and fuzziness of sacroiliac joints

questions.solution:
The X-ray shows a bamboo spine which is suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis, and erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints is the first sign to appear radiographically in ankylosing spondylitis.

Important X-ray features of ankylosing spondylitis:

Sacro-iliac joints:

  • Sacroiliitis is usually the first manifestation and is bilateral and symmetrical.
  • Cardinal sign/earliest sign is the erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints.
  • Later- periarticular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint.

Vertebral changes: 

  • Early spondylitis is characterized by small erosions at the corners of vertebral bodies with reactive sclerosis: Romanus lesions of the spine (Shiny corner sign)
  • Squaring of vertebral bodies or flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the spine due to inflammatory resorption of the bone.
  • Later signs are ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs producing syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae.
  • Bamboo spine appearance is due to bridging at several vertebral levels.
  • Linear ossification along the central spine; representing interspinous ligament ossification can give a Dagger sign appearance on frontal radiographs.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the spine and sacroiliac joints commonly seen in young males. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker.
